title: Soft tech
summary: A poem on what the internet could be...

title: How to fix the internet
summary: "We need to learn to appreciate areas of the internet that are small, like a new Mastodon server or Discord or blog. We need to trust in the power of '1,000 true fans' over cheaply amassed millions."

title: Social Internet Is Dead. Get Over It.
summary: More about the demise of social media than the value of personal websites, but still an important piece of the discourse

title: The Importance of Personal Websites
summary: The author describes some pros and cons of personal websites and how they've set theirs up

title: Web Manifesto
summary: Comprehensive history and the author's personal manifesto, including a great point about discoverability

title: why the web?
summary: "The web will reflect humanity if we put our lives online."

title: Exploring the Personal Web
summary: Includes a great meta-list of Collectives and Projects for identifying other personal websites

title: Why you should have a blog (and write in it)
summary: I like the prompts for what to write

title: My 20th anniversary of blogging!
summary: "People are looking for other people, not performances of personas, and a personal blog is a more likely place to find that than social media these days."

title: Bix's story of his internet
summary: Bix's story of his internet

title: About me (localghost)
summary: "Like many other people in the early 00s, I learnt to build websites by clicking View Source, copying bits I liked, then changing them slightly"

title: At home on the internet
summary: "Personally, I just want a place I can put my stuff online again – without advertising, without engagement gaming, without endless notifications, without audience-building acrobatics."

title: How I experience web today
summary: A painfully familiar parody that shows everything wrong with the web today

title: About this website
summary: "I grew up on the Internet in a time when social media meant writing comments on other people’s hand-built blogs."

title: How the Blog Broke the Web
summary: A critique of reverse chronological sorting and specifically Movable Type.

title: I miss the internet.
summary: "You didn’t so much surf the web as explore it, encountering -- territories and unexpected gems. Websites were less about utility and more about passion. Amateur webmasters crafted their domains as personal expressions, little slices of their world that they invited you into."

title: Every person on the planet should have their own website
summary: Short and to the point

title: Eight years of blogging
summary: "Having a little space on the Web where you can do whatever the heck you want is fun. Using it for learning new skills and teaching others is fun. Exchanging links with others is fun!"

title: Blogging is alive and well
summary: Optimism that we'll continue to see a resurgence of personal websites

title: The Year of the Personal Website
summary: Call to action to make 2023 the year of the personal website

title: Bring back personal blogging
summary: "The personal blog built the internet, and maybe it can fix it."

title: Passionless Web
summary: Manu writes about personal websites quite frequently; this is one piece of many. Check out his archives for more.

title: Building a Digital Homestead, Bit by Brick
summary: "A personal site, or a blog, is more than just a collection of writing. It’s a kind of place - something that feels like home among the streams."

title: Early Web Design Helped a Generation Express Themselves Online. How Do We Capture That Feeling Again?
summary: This article focuses on design aspects of early websites and the creativity unlocked by that environment

title: The Joys and Sorrows of Maintaining a Personal Website
summary: "As someone running a personal website, you are like the neighborhood cobbler competing against the national chain stores. You know your product is superior, but you still have no hope of prevailing. Your best possible outcome is merely surviving to continue the struggle."

title: On building a home on the web
summary: "Stumbling upon these websites was a bit like walking into their physical house, leaving your shoes by the door and, glass in hand, taking a peek at the spines of their books, their record collection, the picture frames on the wall, or the tidbits they displayed on the sideboard."

title: How Websites Die
summary: "It pains me to see people build websites with no feeling of obligation to them — when you put something out into the world, it is your responsibility to care for it."

title: “Tom had us all doing front-end web development”: a nostalgic (re)imagining of Myspace
summary: Fascinating academic paper studying shifts in Twitter discourse surrounding MySpace, with a callout for girls and BIPOC youth who were able to learn basic coding and other technical skills via their pages

title: Why Personal Websites are Important
summary: "Your website should be the primary place where all of the stuff you create goes. It should be THE place for people to find and communicate with you."

title: The Value of a Personal Site
summary: Personal sites can be used for learning technologies and sharing learnings

title: envisioning my homepage as an online therapeutic space
summary: Winnie has written a lot about her presence on the web, why she writes, and personal websites in general.

title: Hunting the Nearly-Invisible Personal Website
summary: Humorous article that compares the personal website to a rare species

title: What is the Small Web?
summary: Includes a nice mental model of the small web scaling horizontally, unlike the corporate web which scales vertically

title: Rediscovering the Small Web
summary: "A painter wouldn’t add more red to her painting or change the composition because market data showed that people liked it better. It’s her creative vision; some people might like it, others might not."

title: On attention management & owning your content
summary: "The internet became a terrible place. It seems that today we need to give our data, content and attention to others in order to receive a virtual form of social affirmation. This is my answer to that."

title: Stop Crowdsourcing Your Confidence
summary: This one is less about personal websites and more about how social media can be toxic. The ideas are important in the overall discourse.

title: Homesteading 2014
summary: "In light of the noisy, fragmented internet, I want a unified place for myself—the internet version of a quiet, cluttered cottage in the country."

title: Death to Bullshit
summary: "...we as creators have a decision to make: do we want to be part of the 90% of noise out there, or do we want to be part of the 10% of signal?"

title: A Brief History & Ethos of the Digital Garden
summary: While not the same as personal blogs, digital gardens are adjacent, and lately it feels like adoption within the personal website-verse is increasing. This is a solid history (with illustrations!) and detailed exposition on the concept.

title: E/N (Everything/Nothing)
summary: The everything/nothing concept never quite took off the way "blogs" or "digital gardens" have, but I think it's an important piece of web history and gets at the core of why personal websites are important even if it feels like no one else cares about yours except you
